metadata.title: Python nidoviruses, more than respiratory pathogens 2 3 4 Running title: Systemic nidovirus infection Institute of Veterinary Pathology

affiliation.laboratory: Servei de Diagnostic en Patologia Veterinaria (SDPV)

abstract.text: In recent years nidoviruses have emerged as an important respiratory pathogen of reptiles, 29 affecting especially captive python populations. In pythons, nidovirus infection induces an 30 inflammation of the upper respiratory and alimentary tract which can develop into a severe and 31 often fatal proliferative pneumonia. We observed pyogranulomatous and fibrinonecrotic lesions 32 in organ systems other than the respiratory tract during full post mortem examinations on 30 33 nidovirus RT-PCR positive pythons of varying species originating from Switzerland and Spain.

The observations prompted us to study whether the atypical tissue tropism associates with 35 previously unknown nidoviruses or changes in the nidovirus genome. RT-PCR and inoculation 36 of Morelia viridis cell cultures served to recruit the cases and to obtain virus isolates. 37 Immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence staining against nidovirus nucleoprotein 38 demonstrated that the virus not only infects a broad spectrum of epithelial (respiratory and 39 alimentary epithelium, hepatocytes, renal tubules, pancreatic ducts etc.), but also intravascular 40 monocytes, intralesional macrophages and endothelial cells. By next-generation sequencing we 41 obtained full length genome for a novel nidovirus species circulating in Switzerland. Analysis of 42 viral genomes recovered from pythons showing nidovirus infection-associated respiratory or 43 systemic disease did not explain the observed phenotypes. The results indicate that python 44 nidoviruses have a broad cell and tissue tropism, further suggesting that the course of infection 45 could vary and involve lesions in a broad spectrum of tissues and organ systems as a 46 consequence of monocyte-mediated systemic spread of the virus. 47 48 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. IMPORTANCE 49 During the last years, python nidoviruses have become a primary cause of fatal disease in 50 pythons. Nidoviruses represent a threat to captive snake collections, as they spread rapidly and 51 can be associated with high morbidity and mortality. Our study indicates that, different from 52 previously evidence, the viruses do not only affect the respiratory tract, but can spread in the 53 entire body with blood monocytes, have a broad spectrum of target cells, and can induce a 54 variety of lesions. Nidovirales is an order of animal and human viruses that compromise 55 important zoonotic pathogens such as MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV, as well as the recently 56 emerged SARS-CoV-2. Python nidoviruses belong to the same subfamily as the mentioned 57 human viruses and show similar characteristics (rapid spread, respiratory and gastrointestinal 58 tropism, etc.). The present study confirms the relevance of natural animal diseases to better 59 understand the complexity of viruses of the order nidovirales.
60 61 62 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

Therefore, we undertook a larger study, making use of diagnostic (Table 1 ) as described (6). 168 Library preparation, data analysis, and genome assembly was done as described (6). 169 To study the frequencies of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) within samples, the NGS 170 reads were quality filtered using Trimmomatic and the reads with Q-score over 30 were 171 assembled against the consensus sequence of a given sample using the BWA-MEM algorithm 172 (15) followed by removal of potential PCR duplicates using SAMTools version 1.8 (16). Gross presentation of nidovirus-associated disease in pythons. 197 Full post mortem examinations were performed on all cases. Most snakes that had died 198 spontaneously exhibited the typical, previously described respiratory changes, represented by a 199 varying amount of mucoid material in the airways and particularly in the lungs (Fig. 1A) . In 200 some animals, the oral cavity, the trachea, the lung and the air sacs were filled with mucoid 201 material and the lung parenchyma appeared thickened (nidovirus-associated proliferative 202 disease; Fig.1A) ; also, the mucoid material was occasionally mixed with purulent exudate. Two 203 euthanized carpet pythons with clinically reported respiratory distress (CH-B1 and -B2, Table 1) 204 did not exhibit any gross pulmonary changes, but showed mild mucus accumulation in the oral 205 cavity. In others, granulomatous and/or fibrinonecrotic lesions were observed in the oral, Table 1 . Oral cavity and respiratory tract. The respiratory tract was found to be affected in all animals and degenerated oral and nasal epithelial cells (Fig. 1D ). In two euthanized carpet pythons (CH-221 B1 and -B2, Table 1 ), these were the only pathological changes, suggesting that they represented 222 early (initial) lesions. The latter is further supported by the fact that in one of the two individuals disease. In all snakes with the above-described intestinal changes (CH-A7 and -A8, CH-B6, CH-244 F1), the mucosal lesions were found to overlie focal inflammatory processes in the intestinal 245 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

These were represented by multifocal (pyo)granulomatous perivascular infiltrates of 246 macrophages and fewer heterophils and lymphocytes which were predominantly seen in the 247 submucosa in close proximity to the gut associated lymphatic tissue (GALT) but occasionally 248 extended into the tunica muscularis (Fig. 2C, E) . These lesions contained abundant nidovirus NP The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.10.036640 doi: bioRxiv preprint to the inflammatory foci (e.g. pancreatic ducts, renal tubules etc.) without any evidence of (Fig. 3D ). In two cases (CH-B6 and -F1) ependymal cells were also 283 found to be infected, without evidence of correlating brain lesions (Fig 5D) . Table 1 ) and three positive liver specimens (CH-A7, -A8 and CH-B6, viruses had less than 5 % nucleotide and less than 2.4 % amino acid differences with recently 299 described Morelia viridis nidovirus isolates BH128 14-12 and BH171 14-7 and Serpentovirinae 300 sp isolates L3, L4 and H0-1, but more than 13 % nucleotide and 8.5 % amino acid differences to 301 all other nidovirus strains. Phylogenetic analysis based on ORF1b suggested that these virus 302 forms a sister clade to the previously known python-associated nidovirus species; BPNV and 303 MVNV (Fig 6) . CDSs of the same virus species were obtained from 11 cell culture supernatants, 304 including the isolation attempts from the liver samples included in the NGS analysis. One of the 305 cell culture supernatants analyzed by NGS yielded CDS of MVNV (animal E-C1, Table 1 ), and 306 for four cell culture supernatants NGS failed due to severe bacterial contamination.

For three snakes (CH-A7-8, CH-C3, Table 1 ) the analysis included cell culture isolated virus 308 (lung homogenate as inoculum) and virus sequenced directly from tissue (liver). The consensus 309 sequences obtained from liver tissue and the respective cell culture isolate were identical for 310 each of these three snakes indicating that isolation did not induce a marked bias in the sequence The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.10.036640 doi: bioRxiv preprint

In addition to the above snakes, we studied choanal and/or cloacal swabs from seven additional 369 animals from different collections for the presence of nidovirus RNA by RT-PCR. All of the 370 tested animals were found positive for nidovirus infection (Table 1) Table 1 ), and a necrotzing splenitis (CH-A1 and CH-C4, Table 1 ) and fibrinonecrotic enteritis 380 with intralesional coccoid bacterial colonies (E-B1, Table 1 ). Both conditions are likely a 381 consequence of debilation/dehydration due to chronic pulmonary disease. 382 383 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.10.036640 doi: bioRxiv preprint DISCUSSION 384 Nidoviruses have recently been described as the cause of respiratory tract disease in several 385 python species in the USA and Europe (5, 6, 10, 11), representing an emerging threat to python 386 traders and breeders in particular. The present study aimed to further elucidate the characteristics 387 and relevance of python nidoviruses. Particular emphasis was laid on the potential species 388 specificity of and/or susceptibility to the viruses, their phylogeny and geographic divergence as 389 well as viral shedding and transmission, host cell tropism and type of associated disease. 390 Experimental infection has been shown to reproduce the naturally occurring respiratory disease 391 (7), so our study focused on natural cases from different geographic regions, from breeding 392 colonies that often kept several python species, and from colonies that at least partly worked 393 closely together, exchanging animals. In our study, no differences were noted between the python species in the degree and distribution The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.10.036640 doi: bioRxiv preprint suggest increased susceptibility of snakes from this genus to nidovirus infection and/or disease, a 409 finding also supported by recent epidemiologic studies (14). In support, the analysis of the viral 410 genomes by NGS did not show differences in the viral genome that would explain the 411 differences in the disease manifestation. One could speculate that each python species has its 412 own nidovirus, and that cross-species transmission of the viruses results in morbidity. Should The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.10.036640 doi: bioRxiv preprint The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.10.036640 doi: bioRxiv preprint Table 1 . Animals, clinical signs, lesions and viral target cells. All animals were from breeding collections in Switzerland (CH) or Spain (E). Breeders CH A-C and CH-F were working closely together, trading/exchanging snakes.

FIGREF0.text: 90 cases with natural nidovirus infection. A total of 30 nidovirus infected snakes, selected based on 91 demonstration of nidovirus nucleoprotein (NP) by immunohistology in tissues with lesions. Six 92 python species from nine breeding colonies and collections were included, namenly the green 93 tree python (Morelia viridis), woma python (Aspidites ramsayi), carpet python (Morelia spilota), 94 Angolan python (Python anchietae), ball python (Python regius), Indian python (Python 95 molurus), and the black-headed python (Aspidites melanocephalus). Immunohistology also 96 helped to identify the nidovirus target cells (6), and next-generation sequencing (NGS) served to 97 obtain complete or near complete genomes of the causative viruses. The results support the 98 hypothesis that nidovirus infections can cause variable disease in pythons, with lesions in a broad 99 spectrum of tissues and organs, and monocyte-mediated systemic spread of the virus.

FIGREF1.text: in PBS) overnight at 4 °C, washed five times with PBS, and incubated for 30 min at RT 154 with Alexa Fluor 488-labeled donkey anti-goat immunoglobulin secondary antibody (Invitrogen; 155 1:500 in PBS), followed by a 15 min incubation with DAPI (4′, 6-diamidino-2-phenylindole, 156 Novus Biologicals; 1:10,000 in PBS). Sections were washed twice with distilled water, air dried, 157 and a coverslip placed with FluoreGuard mounting medium (Biosystems, Switzerland). Images 158 were taken at a 400 x magnification with a Nikon Eclipse Ti-U inverted microscope with NIS 159 Advanced Research software.

FIGREF2.text: Virus isolation. Cultured brain and liver cells of M. viridis, at passage 8-15, were used for 161 inoculations with tissue samples from selected animals (Table 1) as described (6). At 4-5 days 162 post inoculation, the cell culture supernatants were collected for RT-PCR and next generation 163 sequencing (NGS) library preparation.

FIGREF3.text: 164 RT-PCR and NGS. RNA was extracted from lung and/or liver tissue samples of 24 animals, 165 from cotton dry swabs used to sample the choanal and cloacal mucosa of 10 animals, from a lung 166 lavage sample of an adult female ball python (Python regius) from a further Swiss breeder 167 unrelated to any of the others, and from tissue culture supernatants

FIGREF4.text: 173 frequency of single nucleotide variants in each sequence position was called using LoFreq 174 version 2 (17) and the genetic diversity between viral sequences derived from tissue and cell Phylogenetic analysis. The sequences of the representatives of the genus Tobaniviridae were 177 downloaded from the GenBank. The complete genomes of python-associated virus strains were 178 aligned using ClustalW algorithm implemented in the MEGA7 program (19). In addition, the 179 amino acid sequences of ORF1b (RdRp) were aligned with MAFFT version 7.407 using E-INS-i 180 parameters (20). The phylogenetic trees were constructed using the Bayesian Markov chain 181 Monte Carlo (MCMC) method, implemented in Mr. Bayes version 3.2 (21) with two 182 independent runs and four chains per run, the GTR-G-I model of substitution for nucleotides and 183 the WAG model of substitution for amino acids. The analyses were run for 5 million states and 184 sampled every 5,000 steps. 185 Recombination analysis. Recombination events were sought from an alignment containing 186 snake-associated nidoviruses using pairwise homoplasy index (PHI) test (22) implemented in 187 SplitsTree version 4.15.1 (23) and tree order scan method implemented in SSE 1.3 software (24), 188 followed by identification of potentially recombinant sequences and estimation of recombination 189 break points using RDP (25), bootscan (26), maxchi (27), chimaera (28), 3seq (29), geneconv 190 (30) and siscan (31) methods implemented in RDP4 software (32). The potential recombination 191 events detected by at least five out of seven methods were further evaluated by constructing 192 phylogenetic trees using neighbor joining method and maximum composite likelihood 193 substitution model implemented in MEGA7 software (19).

FIGREF7.text: Python nidoviruses have a broad target cell and lesion spectrum.

FIGREF8.text: all animals, the major organs and tissues as well as gross lesions were examined by 211 histology and immunohistology for nidovirus NP. The examination a revealed broad target cell 212 spectrum and nidovirus-associated cytopathic effect.

FIGREF10.text: CH-B1) nidovirus NP was also detected in a few individual respiratory epithelial cells in the 224 trachea, some trabecular pseudostratified lung epithelial cells, and occasional type I pneumocytes 225 lining the faveolar space (Fig. 5A), without evidence of cell damage or inflammation. Two ball 226 pythons with fibrinonecrotic rhinitis and stomatitis (E-B1 and -B3) also exhibited a diffuse 227 chronic tracheitis with subepithelial infiltration by lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages and 228 occasional heterophils, but no further lesions in the lower respiratory tract. 229 The remaining snakes showed histological evidence of nidovirus-associated proliferative disease 230 with epithelial hyperplasia in the nasal cavity, trachea, and lung, as well as mucus and 231 inflammatory cells filling the faveolar space, consistent with our earlier findings (6). Nidovirus 232 NP expression was seen in the pseudostratified epithelium of the primary trabeculae and in type I 233 and type II pneumocytes of the faveolar space; the extent and distribution varied between 234 animals. 235 Alimentary tract. In addition to the respiratory changes, several individuals (CH-A1 and -A9, 236 CH-B6, CH-D1 and -D2, CH-C4, CH-E; carpet pythons, green tree pythons, ball pythons and a 237 black-headed python) exhibited a severe multifocal fibrinonecrotic esophagitis (Fig. 1E, F) with 238 abundant nidovirus-infected intact and degenerate squamous epithelial cells. The gross intestinal 239 lesions observed in another four cases (CH-A7, and -A8, CH-B6, CH-F1) were indeed nidovirus-240 induced, since all exhibited a multifocal fibrinonecrotic enteritis with nidovirus NP expression in 241individual intact and degenerating enterocytes(Fig. 2C, D).

FIGREF11.text: Vascular involvement, systemic spread and systemic granulomatous and/or fibrinonecrotizing

FIGREF13.text: 249in infiltrating macrophages(Fig. 2D, F). Occasional affected vessels also exhibited fibrinoid 250 degeneration of the wall with intramural heterophil infiltration. A multifocal pyogranulomatous 251 vasculitis and perivasculitis of small, medium-sized and large veins and arteries was also seen in 252 the serosa of various organs, e.g. the heart, the lung and the thymus, of four snakes (CH-A7, CH-253 B6, CH-C3, CH-F1) (Fig. 4 C, D). Here, nidovirus NP was not only detected in macrophages of 254 the infiltrates, but also in endothelial cells, which often appeared to be activated (Fig. 2F), and in 255 mononuclear cells in the vessel lumina (Fig. 2F, 4A). Staining for the monocyte/macrophage 256 marker Iba-1 showed that the mononuclear cells in the vessel lumina were predominantly Iba-1 257 positive, i.e. monocytes (Fig. 4B). The latter finding suggests monocyte-associated viremia, and 258 viral spread via infected monocytes. 259 Interestingly, all animals with the described vascular lesions were green tree pythons (CH-A7, 260 CH-B6, CH-C3, CH-F1) and also exhibited multifocal pyogranulomatous lesions, which 261 consisted of a central area of necrosis, surrounded by virus-laden macrophages (Fig. 4 C, D). 262 Affected organs included the kidneys, thymus, heart and liver, and in one animal (CH-C3) the 263 lung. One green tree python (CH-F1) also exhibited pyogranulomatous and fibrinonecrotic 264 lesions in the oviduct, with nidovirus NP found cell-free in necrotic debris. This was seen 265 together with a fibrinous coelomitis in the caudal coelomic cavity, adjacent to the inflamed 266 oviduct. Pyogranulomatous lesions varied in distribution and extent between individuals, but 267were always present in more than one organ. There was no evidence of bacteria within the 268 lesions. Animals with pyogranulomatous lesions often showed nidovirus NP in epithelia adjacent 269 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF14.text: fibrinonecrotic lesions were observed in five green tree pythons (CH-A1 and -A7, CH-272 B6, CH-C3, CH-F1) and one carpet python (CH-B1). They were represented by diffuse necrosis 273 and fibrin exudation in parenchymatous organs (spleen, thymus) or on the serosal surface of the 274 coelomic cavity (in close proximity to affected organs) with minimal inflammatory response 275 (Fig. 4E and F). These lesions were often observed in animals with nidovirus-associated 276 perivascular/vascular and/or pyogranulomatous lesions, indicating massive systemic spread of 277 the virus. 278 Infection of epithelial cells and ependyma. As described, nidovirus NP was detected in various 279 types of epithelial cells, often in close proximity to granulomatous or fibrinonecrotic lesions and 280 without evidence of a cytopathic effect. Affected epithelial cells included type I and type II 281 pneumocytes of the lung, epithelial cells of renal tubules and pancreatic ducts, mesothelial cells 282 (Fig. 5A-C) and hepatocytes

After inoculation, cytopathic effects were 288 observed in 12/24 samples at about 3-4 days post infection (dpi). Two nidovirus positive lung 289 (CH-A8, CH-F2,

FIGREF16.text: 311analysis. Single nucleotide variant (SNV) analysis of the NGS data did not show evidence of amount of phylogeny violations across the genome. Therefore, we conducted a more detailed 320 recombination analysis. This analysis suggested at least five highly supported recombination 321 events.322    Morelia viridis nidovirus isolates BH171/14-7 and BH128/14-12 (33) cluster together with 323 Serpentovirinae sp. isolate L1 based on 5' and 3' ends of the genome (corresponding to324 nucleotides 1-14704 and 36100-37869 in the alignment), whereas based on nucleotides 14705-325 25143 and 27808-36099 these strains cluster together with Serpentovirinae sp. isolate H0-1 326 (MN161564), and between nucleotides 25144 and 27807 together with strain CH-F1 327 (MK722373) (Fig 7B). Likewise, strain CH-F1 clusters together with Serpentovirinae sp. isolate 328 L1 and BH171/14-7 on the basis of nucleotides 1-10094 but together with 329 MK722375_Python_regius based on the 3' end of the genome (Fig 7C). This suggests that the 330 Serpentovirinae sp. isolate L1 (MN161567) has been involved in at least two distinct 331 recombination events. Although these four isolates (Serpentovirinae sp. isolate L1, Morelia 332 viridis nidovirus isolates BH171/14-7 and BH128/14-12 and strain CH-F1) cluster together in 333 the 5'end of the genome, the genetic distances between these strains are rather high in this 334 region, suggesting that the exact recombination partners are not represented in the dataset. Since 335 Serpentovirinae sp. isolate L1 was sequenced from a Python regius in the USA in 2015 (14), 336 Sequential exclusion of recombinant regions from the alignment (i.e. nucleotides 1-14704 and 345 25144-37869) resulted in the tree shown in Figure 7E. Although some of the methods included 346 in RDP4 analysis still found evidence of recombination in this alignment, the further removal of 347 these regions did not affect the topology of the tree. 348 The phylogenetic tree indicated that multiple viral strains circulate among the snakes of a single 349 breeder and, on the other hand, there are some indications of viral transmission between the 350 breeders, as exemplified by the high similarity of strains CH-B1, CH-B3 (breeder CH-B) and 351 CH-E2 (breeder CH-E). 352 The breeders CH-A, CH-B, CH-C and CH-F exchanged animals, which may explain the 353 grouping of strains CH-C3, CH-A7, CH-E2, CH-B1, CH-B3, CH-B5 and CH-A8 to a single 354 cluster. Notably, no recombination events were detected between the newly detected nidovirus 355 species and the previously characterized Morelia viridis nidovirus, python nidovirus and ball 356 python nidovirus (Fig 7E), suggesting that recombination occurs only within virus species but 357 not between species. 358 Evidence of horizontal transmission within colonies and of virus shedding from diseased 359 animals 360 One Swiss breeder (CH-B,Table 1) lost one of three juvenile carpet pythons from the same 361 clutch that had been housed separate from each other, but in the same room (distance less than362 0.5 m), to severe fatal proliferative pneumonia (CH-B4). The post mortem examination 363 confirmed nidovirus-associated pneumonia in the deceased animal, prompting the breeder to 364 submit the two siblings (CH-B1 and -B2, Table 1) for euthanasia and diagnostic post mortem 365 examination. Both individuals exhibited nidovirus-associated lesions in the upper airways but 366 not in the lung, suggesting that these cases represented an early disease stage following airborne 367 infection.

FIGREF18.text: nidovirus-associated proliferative disease (respiratory form) and individuals with evidence 372 of granulomatous and fibrinonecrotic disease (systemic form), suggesting that diseased animals 373 shed the virus. Further, the virus strains from snakes CH-B1, CH-B3 and CH-B5 showed high 374 genetic identities and clustered together in the phylogenetic trees suggesting viral transmission 375 between the snakes of breeder CH-B.

FIGREF19.text: Pathological changes unrelated to nidovirus infection 377Individual snakes exhibited additional lesions that appeared to be unrelated to nidovirus 378 infection, as confirmed by immunohistology for nidovirus NP; renal gout (CH-A3 and E-A1,379

FIGREF20.text: Pythons are nonvenomous snakes found in Africa, Asia and Australia. Eight genera and 31 395 species are currently recognized, most are also kept in captivity (34). The present study shows396 that python species originating from three continents are susceptible to python nidoviruses and 397 can develop nidovirus-associated disease. Ball pythons (Python regius (35)) and Angolan 398 pythons (Python anchietae (36)) are closely related and originate from sub-Saharan and southern 399 Africa, respectively. The green tree python (Morelia viridis (Schlegel, 1872)), the carpet python 400 (Morelia spilota (37)) and the Ramsay's python (Aspidites ramsayi, (38)) represent species 401 originating from Australia and New Guinea (Indonesia and Papua New Guinea), whereas the 402 Indian python (Python molurus (39)) is indigenous to the Indian Subcontinent and Southeast 403 Asia.

FIGREF22.text: 405of nidovirus-associated respiratory disease. However, it is interesting to note that all animals406 with systemic viral spread (indicated by disseminated granulomatous and/or fibrinonecrotic 407 lesions, [peri]vascular lesions, infected monocytes etc.) were of the genus Morelia. The results 408 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF23.text: 413 pythons (or snakes in general) indeed be hosts for nidoviruses, then a co-infection with an 414 unidentified bacterial or viral agent could also explain the sudden emergence of fatal pneumonia 415 cases in captive snakes. An alternative explanation for the emergence of nidovirus infections in 416 python collections could be that there have been multiple nidovirus introductions to various 417 python species from an unknown host species or a vector. 418 Recently, experimental infection of ball pythons established the causal relationship between 419 nidovirus infection and mucinous inflammation of the upper respiratory and the gastrointestinal 420 tract as the main pathological process early, i.e. within the first 12 weeks, after infection (7).421 Infected pythons showed severe respiratory distress with only minimal pneumonia, most likely 422 because the mucus overproduction resulted in obstruction of the upper airways (7). These 423 findings correlate with those we made when studying naturally infected cases; some animals 424 were submitted for euthanasia due to acute respiratory distress, but only exhibited inflammatory nidoviruses for which the results of the present study indicate a rather broad cell tropism, for 459 various types of epithelia (respiratory and pulmonary epithelium, enterocytes, hepatocytes, 460 epithelial cells in renal tubules and pancreatic ducts) and ependymal cells. Interestingly, a similar 461 tendency is described for SARS-CoV-2 (54). Previous studies on python nidoviruses have hinted 462 at a broader target cell spectrum, but did so far not go beyond the detection of nidovirus RNA in 463 organs other than the respiratory tract (10), and did neither identify infected cells nor correlate 464 infection with actual organ lesions. 465 Of particular interest is the fact that python nidoviruses also infect non-epithelial cells distributed 466 over the entire body. We detected nidovirus NP in endothelial cells, intravascular monocytes and 467 extravascular macrophages within inflammatory processes. The latter suggest that monocytes 468 facilitate the systemic spread of the virus. So far, viruses of the subfamily Tobaniviridae have 469 not been reported to infect monocytes/macrophages. However, monocyte/macrophage infection 470 is known to be a key process in the pathogenesis of other members of the order Nidovirales, such 471 as feline coronaviruses (FCoV) (55), ferret systemic coronavirus (FRSCV) (56) and Severe 472 Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (SARS-CoV) (57). For FCoV, the ability to infect, 473 replicate in and activate monocytes and macrophages is essential in the pathogenesis of feline 474 infectious peritonitis (FIP), a fatal disease of felids. While the low-virulence feline enteric 475 coronavirus (FECV) biotype primarily replicates in enterocytes and does only induce mild 476 Similar to cats with FIP, systemically nidovirus-infected pythons exhibited a multifocal 484 macrophage-dominated vasculitis which was in severe cases associated with fibrinoid necrosis of 485 the vessel wall, but also appeared as chronic perivascular (pyo)granulomatous cuffs with 486 abundant nidovirus-positive macrophages. These vascular lesions could result from an 487 interaction between activated nidovirus-infected monocytes and endothelial cells, in particular 488 since the latter were also found to become infected. They might also be responsible for the broad 489 spectrum of granulomatous to fibrinonecrotic lesions in organs, since these might at least partly 490 be of ischemic nature. 491 Sequencing of the nidovirus genomes did not reveal variants that would be associated with the 492 systemic infection observed in some individuals. The genome length and relatively high 493 mutation and recombination rate of nidoviruses makes identification of mutations that might 494 alter the pathogenesis of the virus rather challenging. The S protein is the precursor of the spike 495 complex that mediates receptor binding and entry, and thus mutations in the S protein could most 496 easily explain the differences in tissue tropism (62). However, we did not identify S protein 497 mutations that would explain the different phenotypes. One could thus speculate that the 498 different infection outcome is a consequence of differences in the host immune response. 499 During viral infections of mammals, viruses are recognized by pattern recognition receptors 500 (PRRs) which induce a type I interferon (IFN) response, mediated by IFN-α and -β. The IFN 501 response is considered the primary host defense mechanism against viral infections. It is 502 therefore not surprising that many viruses have developed mechanisms to subvert or alter the 503 type I IFN response (61). Interference of nidoviruses with the IFN response has so far mainly 504 been investigated in the family Coronaviridae. In studies on human SARS-CoV infection the 505 presence of viral proteins in monocytes was not found to be associated with significant IFN-α 506 production and it was suggested that viral particles had been taken up by monocytes via 507 phagocytosis. This correlates with studies on IFN receptor deficient knock-out mice where MHV Python nidovirus disease. Lesions in the oral cavity and esophagus. A, B. The esophagus exhibits a severe multifocal fibrinonecrotic inflammation 516 (arrow). Inset: lung after longitudinal section, with accumulation of abundant mucoid fluid in the 517 lumen. B. Oral cavity, ventral aspect. Focal fibrinonecrotic stomatitis (arrows). C, D. Snake CH-518 A4 (Woma python; Aspidites ramsayi). Nasal mucosa. Severe fibrinonecrotic rhinitis (C). Snake 540 CH-C3 (Green tree python; M. viridis). B. Focal granuloma (arrows). HE stain. Bar = 20 µm. C. 541 Closer view of granuloma, with central area of necrosis (asterisk), surrounded by numerous 542 macrophages that exhibit strong nidovirus NP expression (arrows). Viral antigen expression is 543 also seen in Kupffer cells (arrowheads). Immunohistology, hemalaun counterstain. Bar = 50 µm. 544 D. Double immunofluorescence of the granuloma confirms nidovirus NP expression (red) within 545 macrophages (Iba-1+; green; arrows) and a Kupffer cell (asterisk). There is also a hepatocyte 546 with weak nidovirus NP expression (arrowhead).

FIGREF29.text: Maximum clade credibility tree constructed from the ORF1b amino acid sequences of 571 representatives of the family Tobaniviridae. The phylogenetic tree was constructed using the 572 Bayesian MCMC method with the WAG model of substitution. Posterior probabilities are shown 573 at each node.

(B-D) Incongruent tree 577 topologies of virus strains with highly supported recombination events estimated using RDP 578 software. The numbers above trees show the genome regions in alignment. (E) Phylogenetic tree 579 based on concatenated non-recombinant genome regions.
